1.title: "Football, the Great All-American Sport"

2.heading: Pusey, J. Carver--Miscellanea.
2.title: Comics and Their Creators
2.author: edited by Gary Usher.
notes: Compiled in photocopy from the weekly Literary Digest from Nov. 25, 1933 to June 15, 1935.
Each page includes biographical sketch, photographic portrait and sample drawing.

3.heading: Pusey, J. Carver--Miscellanea.
3.title: "Fortune Tellers" p. 11 in Hogan's Alley, v. 2, no. 4
3.author: [No author]
notes: Takes the income of 17 cartoonists in 1933, as reported in Fortune magazine, and presents updated equivalents: Bud Fisher, Harold Gray, George McManus, Sidney Smith, Rube Goldberg, Percy Crosby, Fontaine Fox, Harry Tuthill, Billy DeBeck, Frank Willard, Sol Hess. H.T. Webster, Frank King, Cliff Sterrett, George Herriman, Milt Gross and J. Carver Pusey.

4.heading: Pusey, J. Carver--Miscellanea.
4.title: The Funny Papers.
4.author: [No author]
notes: Detached from: Fortune, v. 7, no. 4 (Apr. 1933).

Summary: Discusses the business aspects of the newspaper comics, with sample comics reprinted mostly in color, and portraits (mostly photographic) of J. Carver Pusey, Rube Goldberg, Edgar Rice Burroughs, George Herriman, Fontaine Fox, Milt Gross, Rea Irvin, H.T. Webster, Sidney Smith, Percy Crosby, Billy De Beck, Cliff Sterrett, and George McManus.

23.heading: Push Mowers.
23.title: "The Adamant Spaghetti"
23.author: [No author]
23.series: Another True Life Adventure of Cub Calloway, Ace Reporter) p. 1-2 in Dan O'Neill's Comics and Stories, v. 2, no. 2
notes: The spaghetti was terrorizing the town, and was finally stopped with a push lawnmower.

24.heading: Push Mowers.
24.title: "Better Run For It, Baxter"
24.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Neighbor Harvey Baxter is in his yard with his push mower as Amos' father leaves on his motorcycle; Amos is about to launch a story about a special assignment for the governor.

25.heading: Push Mowers.
25.title: "Child Labor"
25.author: Hanan.
notes: Summary: A little boy cries to get Louie to let him push the lawnmower, and a woman swats Louie with her umbrella for making the boy mow the lawn.
Wordless strip.

26.heading: Push Mowers.
26.title: "The Garden"
26.author: Gregg Miller
notes: About a push lawnmower.

27.heading: Push Mowers.
27.title: "How About Mowing Our Lawn, Leroy?"
27.author: by Hoest & Reiner.
notes: Summary: Leroy is using his push mower in a sunbathing neighbor's yard.

28.heading: Push Mowers.
28.title: "Is It Too Early to Say, Wait Till Next Year?"
28.author: Art-Chip.
notes: They've played the first game of the season. Brutus is standing with a push mower.

29.heading: Push Mowers.
29.title: "A Little Exercise would do you a World of Good, Bruno"
29.author: M
notes: Summary: Fergus mowing the lawn with a push mower, and finds Bruno grown over with grass and flowers.

30.heading: Push Mowers.
30.title: "Look What I Get Done While I Ain't Even Here!"
30.author: J
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: He has attached a reel of pictures to the push mower, belted to the lower roller. Passers-by are each expected to mow enough lawn to see all the pictures.

31.heading: Push Mowers.
31.title: "Mother Won't Be Here With You for a While After This Week"
31.author: King.
notes: Summary: Nina tells Chipper and Clovia she's going to help Corky and Hope at the diner, while Skeezix oils the push mower.

32.heading: Push Mowers.
32.title: "No Short Cuts"
32.author: by Al Vermeer.
notes: Summary: Carlyle wants to work hard and be an Eagle Scout, and Pop with the push mower suggests he could start by clipping the edges of the lawn.

33.heading: Push Mowers.
33.title: "The Other Side of the Fence"
33.author: Ferd & Tom Johnson.
notes: Summary: Brandishing her rolling pin, Mamie tells Willie to push the lawnmower, but she doesn't say where. He heads for Teddy's Tavern.

34.heading: Push Mowers.
34.title: "Sap, That's Your Own Lawnmower Gabby Borrowed Last Week"
34.author: by Swan.
notes: Summary: He buys a push mower at the garage sale next door, and Helen recognizes it.

35.heading: Push Mowers.
35.title: "She Loves Me Not"
35.author: by Doug Marlette.
notes: Reprinted in Kudzu (Ballantine Books, 1982)
Summary: Kudzu admires a patch of daisies, but when they say Veranda loves him not he mows them down with a push mower.
- Call no.: PN6728.K8M37 1982

36.heading: Push Mowers.
36.title: "Something Has Been Added"
36.author: by Al Vermeer.
notes: Summary: Pop's using the push mower with two kids riding on his back: "Before we were married I could cut a lawn twice this big without getting tired!"

37.heading: Push Mowers.
37.title: "That's a Push Mower"
37.author: Bittle.
notes: Summary: Mr. Purvis asks for help starting his lawnmower.

38.heading: Push Mowers.
38.title: "That's Right, Just Lift Your Feet Like You Do When I'm Sweeping the Rug"
38.author: by George Clark.
notes: Summary: She's using a push mower; he's in a lawn chair.

39.heading: Push Mowers.
39.title: "Uncle Charlie Adapted to Automation 20 Years Ago"
39.author: by George Clark.
notes: Summary: Uncle Charlie's in his hammock, and his push mower is almost hidden in the tall grass of his lawn.

40.heading: Push Mowers.
40.title: "We Stayed Home All Those Years While He Studied Nights. Now He's an Executive and Trying to Break 80 at Golf"
40.author: Clark.
notes: Situation: Two women talking over their backyard fences; a push mower leans against a house in an unmowed lawn.

41.heading: Push Mowers.
41.title: "Well, I Hope It Doesn't Work!"
41.author: J
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)

Summary: The boy has combined a wagon and a push mower in such a way that a wheel of the wagon should turn the drive wheel of the mower, and the mower should then cut the tall grass off several inches above the ground, "them babies that duck when th' mower goes over 'em, then pop right up again!" His mother figures he's then going to charge her twice for mowing the lawn.

42.heading: Push Mowers.

42.author: Bob Montana.
notes: Summary: The teenagers are talking about a remote control mower, or artificial grass, and Archie's dad thinks they're lazy.

183.heading: Pustz, Matthew J., 1968-

183.author: by Matthew Pustz.
notes: 18 leaves : ill. ; 28 cm.
Presented at the Joint National Conference of the Popular Culture and American Culture Associations, March 31-April 3, 2010.
Includes bibliographical references (leaf 9).
Summary: Compares the post-apocalyptic Killraven stories in Amazing Adventures, with Conan the Barbarian stories.

185.heading: Pustz, Matthew J., 1968-
185.title: Comic Books and American Cultural History : an Anthology
185.author: edited by Matthew Pustz.

publication info.place: Contents: Comic books as history teachers / Matthew Pustz ; How Wonder Woman helped my students "join the conversation"
publication info.publisher: comic books as teaching tools in a history methodology course / Jessamyn Neuhaus ; Comics as primary sources : the case of Journey into Mohawk country / Bridget M. Marshall ; Transcending the frontier myth : dime novel narration and (Jesse) Custer's last stand in Preacher / William Grady ; "Duel. I'll give you a DUEL" : intimacy and history in Megan Kelso's Alexander Hamilton trilogy / Alison Mandaville ; American golem : reading America through super-new dealers and the "melting pot" / Martin Lund ; "Dreams may end, but love never does" : marriage and materialism in American romance comics

notes: Includes bibliographical references and index.
